properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant snowfall from Sunday evening into Monday. 10 to 20 centimetres of snow are expected over Central and Eastern Quebec beginning late Sunday evening into Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Possible significant snowfall on Sunday. A developing low pressure system over the American Midwest will affect Southwestern Quebec beginning Sunday afternoon. This system will intensify as it approaches the province. Depending on its track, which is still uncertain, this low pressure system could give significant snowfall amounts and cause strong winds over Southern and Central Quebec Sunday night, especially over regions along the northern banks of the St-Lawrence River. It will then spread to eastern Quebec on Monday. If the expected track remains unchanged, precipitation is expected to begin as snow, then gradually change to rain with a risk of freezing rain during the changeover on Monday morning over most areas. Future weather statements will provide more details as the low pressure system's track as well as precipitation types and amounts become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-21T19:37:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-21T03:38:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1836020036.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant snowfall Sunday evening. Snow is expected over Southern and Central Quebec Sunday night. Snowfall amounts could exceed 15 centimetres for regions north of the St-Lawrence River. Regions near the St-Lawrence River are expected to receive 5 to 10 centimetres before the snow changes to rain late in the night. There is a risk of freezing rain for the north shore of Montreal and the Laurentians during the changeover. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-22T02:17:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-21T10:18:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1761150782.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm continues. A moist and unstable airmass will continue to give snow at times heavy to the Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt route tonight. Further snow accumulations of 10 to 15 cm near the summit can be expected by tomorrow morning. Snow level is currently near 1100 metres and is expected to drop to below 600 overnight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-21T16:58:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-21T01:12:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0736960870.2020
Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions are forecast to develop in Clyde River Saturday night. A disturbance developing over Davis Strait will intensify as it tracks towards Clyde River today. Snow will begin in Clyde River overnight on Saturday and northwest winds will increase to 60 gusting 80 km/h. Blizzard conditions will persist through Sunday before improving Monday morning as snow tapers off and winds diminish. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-22T01:23:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-21T09:24:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0787752837.2020
Area: Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Stagnant winter weather conditions are creating elevated pollution levels. Higher pollution levels are expected to persist through Monday. The Ministry of Environment and ClimateChange Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Valemount due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5). This advisory remains in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Restrictions on open burning are now in effect for all areas within Robson Valley Timber Supply Area until November 23, 2020 at 9:00 AM local time. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at www.bcairquality.ca Mandatory Emission Reduction Actions: As pollution is occurring or is likely to occur from open burning, pursuant to Section 30 (1) and (2) of the Open Burning Smoke Control Regulation, the Director has prohibited open burning in the Robson Valley Timber Supply Area until November 23, 2020 at 9:00 AM local time. No vegetative debris may be ignited or added to ignited piles. Contravention of these provisions may be subject to a fine under the Regulation. Voluntary Emission Reduction Actions: Where woodstoves or fireplaces are the sole source of residential heat, burn dry woodand ensure an adequate supply of combustion air. Reduce the use and idling of vehicles. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-11-22T04:29:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-11-21T12:30:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1552120460.2020
Area: Yellowhead
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A Pacific disturbance moving into central Yukon today will create strong east winds of 70 km/h gusting to 90 near the Richardson Mountains by this afternoon. These strong winds will give poor visibility in blowing snow and wind chill values near minus 30. Blizzard conditions will persist through tonight and then end early Sunday morning. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-22T03:20:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-21T11:21:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0338793304.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 20 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system approaching the North Coast today will bring heavy snow near Stewart. The heavy snow will begin this morning then end overnight. Snowfall accumulations of 20 to 30 cm are expected by midnight. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-22T04:35:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-21T12:36:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1766606890.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Stewart
